text:
Memorandum #9
TO: Communications Coordinators, President's Council on
Youth Opportunity
1. Kirk Douglas Film
I am enclosing two 16 mm. prints of a ten minute film
on the need for summer-time opportunity for youth. Kirk
Douglas, filmed in Harlem, and Gregory Peck, in Watts,
present most effectively the need for more opportunity for
inner-city youth. Kirk Douglas also directed the film,
which was produced as a public service by Paramount Pictures.
It originally was produced for theater use, and 35 mm.
prints now are being made available to theaters around the
country. But I thought it also could be of use to you for
television programming, either as an admittedly-lengthy public
service spot, or as part of a discussion program or documentary
on Youth Opportunity. It also could be useful in discussion
groups, at civic club meetings, and other occasions where the
subject is appropriate.
In re television use: Vice President Humphrey closes the
film. Obviously, his participation is an appeal for help in
the Youth Opportunity program. However, since it is an election
year and Mr. Humphrey is a candidate, TV stations may have
logical questions about using it. The head of our audioÂ¬
visual department checked a print, and said it would be possible
to take off the close and splice it back after use without
loss of quality until after several such editings and resplicings.
